title: 110_s3545
content: The Act titled "Investment in After-School Programs Act of 2008" introduces amendments to the Consolidated Farm and Rural Development Act by adding a new section 366 for after-school programs. The "Investment in After-School Programs Act of 2008" introduces a new section 366 aimed at enhancing after-school programs in rural areas by helping communities establish or improve existing programs. It defines after-school programs as activities that promote academic achievement and positive youth development, and eligible entities as local educational agencies or community-based organizations. The "Investment in After-School Programs Act of 2008" establishes grants for after-school programs in rural areas, serving schools with specific locale codes. Grants must be at least $50,000 and have a minimum duration of 3 years. The Secretary may renew a grant for a minimum of 3 years based on performance. Eligible entities must use the grant for projects including transportation, professional development, and technology access. The Secretary can use up to 1% of funds for program evaluations and dissemination of results. The Secretary may allocate up to 3% of funds for outreach, training, and technical assistance in rural areas for afterschool programs. Eligible entities must submit an application to be considered for a grant under this section. An application for a grant under this section must be submitted with required information, including a description of the after-school program, safety measures, transportation arrangements for participants, and community outreach plans. The grant application must include a description of the after-school program, safety measures, transportation arrangements, community outreach plans, services for children and youth, roles of partners, collaboration with schools, and use of funds to increase non-Federal funds. The grant application must include a description of the after-school program, safety measures, transportation arrangements, community outreach plans, services for children and youth, roles of partners, collaboration with schools, and use of funds to increase non-Federal funds. Priority is given to applications proposing partnerships between eligible entities. Authorization of appropriations is set at $50,000,000 for fiscal year 2009. Authorization of appropriations for the after-school program is set at $50,000,000 for fiscal year 2009, $75,000,000 for 2010, $100,000,000 for 2011, $125,000,000 for 2012, and $150,000,000 for 2013.
